21.69.text: residential institutions, usually known as orphanages.

25.79.text: Most people imagine orphanages as a benign environment

30.52.text: Others know more about the living conditions there,

33.75.text: but still think they're a necessary evil.

36.20.text: After all, where else would we put all of those children

41.75.text: But 60 years of research has demonstrated

45.22.text: that separating children from their families

47.47.text: and placing them in large institutions

49.82.text: seriously harms their health and development,

52.66.text: and this is particularly true for young babies.

56.15.text: As we know, babies are born

62.97.text: During the first three years of life, the brain grows

65.63.text: to its full size, with most of that growth taking place

68.40.text: in the first six months. The brain develops

71.02.text: in response to experience and to stimulation.

74.25.text: Every time a young baby learns something new --

79.59.text: to mimic a movement or a facial expression,

82.58.text: to pick something up, to form a word or to sit up --

86.57.text: new synaptic connections are being built in the brain.

90.15.text: New parents are astonished by the rapidity of this learning.

94.25.text: They are quite rightly amazed and delighted by their children's cleverness.

99.16.text: They communicate their delight to their children,

103.46.text: and a desire to achieve more and to learn more.

107.86.text: This forming of the powerful attachment between child and parent

111.61.text: provides the building blocks for physical, social,

118.33.text: It is the model for all future relationships with friends,

122.54.text: with partners and with their own children.

125.78.text: It happens so naturally in most families

128.20.text: that we don't even notice it. Most of us are unaware

131.30.text: of its importance to human development and, by extension,

134.73.text: to the development of a healthy society.

137.63.text: And it's only when it goes wrong that we start to realize

140.17.text: the importance of families to children.

143.18.text: In August, 1993, I had my first opportunity to witness

147.12.text: on a massive scale the impact on children

151.28.text: of institutionalization and the absence of parenting.

155.68.text: Those of us who remember the newspaper reports

158.12.text: that came out of Romania after the 1989 revolution

161.37.text: will recall the horrors of the conditions in some of those institutions.

165.79.text: I was asked to help the director of a large institution to

168.55.text: help prevent the separation of children from their families.

172.51.text: Housing 550 babies, this was Ceausescu's show orphanage,

176.70.text: and so I'd been told the conditions were much better.

179.62.text: Having worked with lots of young children, I expected

182.07.text: the institution to be a riot of noise,

184.68.text: but it was as silent as a convent.

186.55.text: It was hard to believe there were any children there at all,

189.99.text: yet the director showed me into room after room,

192.63.text: each containing row upon row of cots,

195.64.text: in each of which lay a child staring into space.

201.66.text: In a room of 40 newborns, not one of them was crying.

205.31.text: Yet I could see soiled nappies, and I could see

207.35.text: that some of the children were distressed,

208.92.text: but the only noise was a low, continuous moan.

212.76.text: The head nurse told me proudly,

214.86.text: "You see, our children are very well-behaved."

218.09.text: Over the next few days, I began to realize

220.83.text: that this quietness was not exceptional.

222.89.text: The newly admitted babies would cry for the first few hours,

226.66.text: but their demands were not met, and so eventually

228.65.text: they learned not to bother. Within a few days,

231.33.text: they were listless, lethargic, and staring into space

236.65.text: Over the years, many people and news reports

239.57.text: have blamed the personnel in the institutions

241.74.text: for the harm caused to the children, but often, one member

244.60.text: of staff is caring for 10, 20, and even 40 children.

249.16.text: Hence they have no option but to implement a regimented program.

253.22.text: The children must be woken at 7 and fed at 7:30.

257.10.text: At 8, their nappies must be changed, so a staff member

259.61.text: may have only 30 minutes to feed 10 or 20 children.

262.98.text: If a child soils its nappy at 8:30, he will have to wait

266.67.text: several hours before it can be changed again.

269.63.text: The child's daily contact with another human being

272.28.text: is reduced to a few hurried minutes of feeding and changing,

276.75.text: and otherwise their only stimulation is the ceiling,

279.65.text: the walls or the bars of their cots.

283.78.text: Since my first visit to Ceausescu's institution,

286.68.text: I've seen hundreds of such places across 18 countries,

289.81.text: from the Czech Republic to Sudan.

292.60.text: Across all of these diverse lands and cultures,

295.59.text: the institutions, and the child's journey through them,

301.48.text: Lack of stimulation often leads to self-stimulating behaviors

304.59.text: like hand-flapping, rocking back and forth,

307.53.text: or aggression, and in some institutions, psychiatric drugs

311.34.text: are used to control the behavior of these children,

314.17.text: whilst in others, children are tied up to prevent them

319.26.text: These children are quickly labeled as having disabilities

321.75.text: and transferred to another institution for children with disabilities.

325.19.text: Most of these children will never leave the institution again.

329.53.text: For those without disabilities, at age three,

332.19.text: they're transferred to another institution, and at age seven,

334.74.text: to yet another. Segregated according to age and gender,

338.69.text: they are arbitrarily separated from their siblings,

341.24.text: often without even a chance to say goodbye.

345.13.text: There's rarely enough to eat. They are often hungry.

347.91.text: The older children bully the little ones. They learn to

350.62.text: survive. They learn to defend themselves, or they go under.

353.96.text: When they leave the institution, they find it really difficult

357.52.text: to cope and to integrate into society.

360.82.text: In Moldova, young women raised in institutions

364.07.text: are 10 times more likely to be trafficked than their peers,

368.08.text: and a Russian study found that two years after leaving institutions,

372.23.text: young adults, 20 percent of them had a criminal record,

379.45.text: and 10 percent had taken their own lives.

384.01.text: But why are there so many orphans in Europe

386.89.text: when there hasn't been a great deal of war or disaster in recent years?

390.76.text: In fact, more than 95 percent of these children have living parents,

395.35.text: and societies tend to blame these parents

397.34.text: for abandoning these children, but research shows that

400.10.text: most parents want their children, and that the primary drivers

409.74.text: Many countries have not developed inclusive schools,

412.84.text: and so even children with a very mild disability

415.54.text: are sent away to a residential special school,

419.92.text: The institution may be hundreds of miles away from the family home.

424.06.text: If the family's poor, they find it difficult to visit,

426.78.text: and gradually the relationship breaks down.

430.90.text: Behind each of the million children in institutions,

434.20.text: there is usually a story of parents who are desperate

437.96.text: and feel they've run out of options, like Natalia in Moldova,

443.07.text: who only had enough money to feed her baby,

445.46.text: and so had to send her older son to the institution;

448.64.text: or Desi, in Bulgaria, who looked after her four children

451.68.text: at home until her husband died,

454.31.text: but then she had to go out to work full time,

456.56.text: and with no support, felt she had no option

458.70.text: but to place a child with disabilities in an institution;

462.53.text: or the countless young girls too terrified to tell their parents

465.69.text: they're pregnant, who leave their babies in a hospital;

469.27.text: or the new parents, the young couple who have

472.01.text: just found out that their firstborn child has a disability,

476.51.text: and instead of being provided with positive messages

479.57.text: about their child's potential, are told by the doctors,

482.41.text: "Forget her, leave her in the institution,

485.47.text: go home and make a healthy one."

488.99.text: This state of affairs is neither necessary nor is it inevitable.

492.52.text: Every child has the right to a family, deserves

495.65.text: and needs a family, and children are amazingly resilient.

499.48.text: We find that if we get them out of institutions and into loving

502.16.text: families early on, they recover their developmental delays,

505.68.text: and go on to lead normal, happy lives.

508.73.text: It's also much cheaper to provide support to families

512.29.text: than it is to provide institutions.

514.81.text: One study suggests that a family support service

518.00.text: costs 10 percent of an institutional placement,

526.17.text: If we spend less on these children but on the right services,

529.21.text: we can take the savings and reinvest them in high quality

533.17.text: residential care for those few children with extremely complex needs.

537.82.text: Across Europe, a movement is growing to shift the focus

542.35.text: and transfer the resources from large institutions

545.19.text: that provide poor quality care to community-based services

549.15.text: that protect children from harm and allow them to develop

551.87.text: to their full potential. When I first started to work in Romania

555.70.text: nearly 20 years ago, there were 200,000 children living

559.48.text: in institutions, and more entering every day.

563.04.text: Now, there are less than 10,000, and

565.35.text: family support services are provided across the country.

568.80.text: In Moldova, despite extreme poverty and the terrible effects

572.58.text: of the global financial crisis, the numbers of children

575.57.text: in institutions has reduced by more than 50 percent

578.36.text: in the last five years, and the resources are being

581.57.text: redistributed to family support services and inclusive schools.

586.23.text: Many countries have developed national action plans for change.

589.46.text: The European Commission and other major donors

591.98.text: are finding ways to divert money from institutions

598.45.text: to look after their own children.

601.18.text: But there is still much to be done to end the systematic

606.35.text: Awareness-raising is required at every level of society.

609.42.text: People need to know the harm that institutions cause to children,

612.95.text: and the better alternatives that exist.

615.91.text: If we know people who are planning to support orphanages,

618.87.text: we should convince them to support family services instead.

622.91.text: Together, this is the one form of child abuse

626.18.text: that we could eradicate in our lifetime.
